Researchers tracked the amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (measured in picograms) over time beginning with a single cell and continuing through several rounds of cell division. The researchers observed threadlike chromosomes prior to cell division. The threadlike chromosomes disappeared from view shortly after each division. The amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in picograms per cell over several rounds of cell division is shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1. Amount of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in picograms per cell over several rounds of cell division

Which of the following statements is consistent with the data in Figure 1?

choices.label: The cells have a haploid chromosome number of 3.
The cells have a diploid chromosome number of 6.

There is a change from 3 to 6 picograms of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is replicated before each round of cell division.

There is a change from 6 to 3 picograms of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> after each cell division because the chromosomes lengthen following cell division.

content.answer: There is a change from 3 to 6 picograms of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is replicated before each round of cell division.
